s.text: And you also get a lot of rapid reaction to things like Alan Greenspan speeches or employment-cost-index numbers.

There are lots of momentum traders and day traders and technical traders, but there always have been, and in any case the increased volume on the stock market and the greater number of traders has almost certainly made stock prices more efficient and more accurate indicators of underlying value than they once were.

But what bond traders' reliance on technical analysis--the idea that future price movements can be deduced by studying the patterns of past price movements--speaks to is just how impossible it is to successfully predict a market in which every piece of potential information seems to point in two different directions at once, and in which there seems to be nothing that doesn't count as potential information.
This doesn't mean that the bond market is any less efficient than the stock market, though it does seem a bit curious.
This doesn't mean that the bond market is any less efficient than the stock market, though it does seem a bit curious.
